sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a circular loop
message_1: What is the magnetic field at the center of a circular loop of radius 0.1 meters, which carries a current of 2 Amperes?
message_2:
To find the magnetic field at the center of a circular loop, we can use the formula:

B = (μ₀ * I) / (2 * R)

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, and R is the radius of the loop.

Given the radius R = 0.1 meters and the current I = 2 Amperes, we can calculate the magnetic field:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A) / (2 * 0.1 m)

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm) / 0.2 m

B ≈ (40 × 10^(-7) T) / 0.2 m

B ≈ 200 × 10^(-7) T

B ≈ 2 × 10^(-5) T

The magnetic field at the center of the circular loop is approximately 2 × 10^(-5) Tesla.
